text: Alaric I, also Alaricus, (reigned 394–410 AD) was a leader of the Visigoths.John Middleton, World Monarchies and Dynasties, Volume 1–3 (London; New York: Routledge, 2015), p. 995 He is famous as the Gothic leader who sacked the city of Rome in 410 AD.Stan Russo, The 50 Most Significant Individuals in Recorded History (Madison, WI: Inklings Press, 2005), p. 24 Very little about his family is known. As a young man he received much of his military training in the Roman army. He next appears as a war leader of Gothic forces fighting along with Roman troops at the Battle of the Frigidus in 394. In January 395, Emperor Theodosius I died dividing his empire between his two sons. Alaric revolted and as the leader of the Visigoths he attacked parts of the Eastern Roman Empire. He later attacked the Western Roman Empire. In 408 he attempted to attack Rome but was bribed to leave. He returned two years later and defeated and occupied the city. He died in 411. == Life == Alaric was born on an island on the delta of the Danube River.Arthur A. Jones; Robin Wiseman, The Goths: Children of the Storm (New York, NY; Bloomington, IN: ¡Universe Inc., 2009), p. 142 He was a member of the noble Balti dynasty of Visigoths.Dictionary of Greek and Roman biography and mythology, Vol I, ed. William Smith (London: Walton and Maberly, 1861), pp. 88–89 He was first mentioned in 394 AD as a commander under the Roman Emperor Theodosius I in his war against Eugenius. He became the leader or king of the Visigoths in the mid 390s. Alaric rebelled against Emperor Arcadius in 395 and invaded Greece.A Dictionary of Christian Biography, Literature, Sects and Doctrines, Vol I, eds. William Smith; Henry Wace (Boston: Little, Brown & Company, 1877), pp. 68–69 When he came to the walls of Athens, the city paid a heavy ransom and so he left them unharmed.Henry Bradley, The Goths: From the Earliest Times to the End of the Gothic Dominion in Spain, Second Edition (London: T. Fisher Unwin, 1890), pp. 85–88 He then defeated Corinth, Argos and Sparta. He continued to lay waste to Greece until 397 when Roman General Stilicho surrounded Alaric's army at Arcadia. The Romans cut off the water to the Gothic camp and thought that it was impossible for Alarc to escape. Howeverm Alaric broke through their lines and marched to the north over very difficult terrain. Alaric then made a treaty with Arcadius. Stilicho returned to Italy without having defeated Alaric. In 401-402 AD Alaric entered Italy. He tried the same tactics that he had used earlier but was unsuccessful against the Roman army. At the Battle of Pollentia in 402, the Roman Army defeated the Goths. Alaric's wife was one of those captured by the Romans. However, the Visigoth losses were very few, and Alaric's army left in good order. Alaric crossed the Po River intending on attacking Rome but was met and defeated again by Stilicho at the Battle of Verona. Alaric's army attacked across the Danube and Rhine Rivers again in 405 and 406 AD. Stilicho, who was now ruling in the name of Emperor Honorius, made a treaty with Alaric. But Stilicho was killed in 408. Alaric invaded Italy again and demanded for Stilicho's promises to be kept. == Fall of Rome == From late 408 AD, the Visigoth Army camped outside Rome. Alaric demanded payment from Honorius, who was safe in Ravenna, which the emperor refused to pay. Zosimus the historian wrote the only known account of the last negotiations before Rome was sacked: On August 24, 410 AD, Rome's city gates were opened by slaves. Alaric's Visigoths began three days of murdering and plundering. However, according to Augustine of Hippo their fury was bridled for the Christians of the city: "their furious rage for slaughter was bridled, and their eagerness to take prisoners was quenched. Thus escaped multitudes who now reproach the Christian religion, and impute to Christ the ills that have befallen their city; but the preservation of their own lives — a boon which they owe to the respect entertained for Christ by the barbarians". They damaged buildings and stole from tombs of former emperors. It was the first time in 800 years that Rome was sacked, but the Visigoths continued their destruction further south in Italy. The casualties were high on both sides. The Romans lost an estimated 15,000 men while the Visigoths lost about 17,000. Alaric planned to move his army into Sicily and then on to Africa. Howeverm he died soon after Rome fell in 410 AD. Ataulf succeeded Alaric as king and took his army into Gaul. == References == == Other websites == * Alaric - The Fall of Rome - with Rome total war * Alaric leader of the Visigoths Category:4th- century births Category:Ancient Rome Category:410s deaths Category:Visigothic kings
